articles.headline: ‘President Trump?’ Here’s How He Says It Would Look
articles.snippet: The presumptive Republican nominee has already been giving some thought to what he would do in his first hundred days in office.
articles.abstract: The presumptive Republican nominee has already been giving some thought to what he would do in his first hundred days in office.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is now the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, but he is also keenly aware that many in his own party — and many Americans, frankly — are scared and anxious about the idea of him in the Oval Office. Even he is not sure how a deeply divided nation would adjust to the first 100 days of a Trump presidency.

articles.headline: Takata Airbag Defect Is Traced to Moisture and Temperature
articles.snippet: Based on the findings of three investigations, American regulators will order replacements in 35 million to 40 million vehicles.
articles.abstract: Based on the findings of three investigations, American regulators will order replacements in 35 million to 40 million vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: As recalls of defective airbags made by Takata mushroomed from a few thousand in 2008 to tens of millions, a central mystery remained: What was causing the airbags to rupture violently, sending metal fragments flying into the cabin.

articles.headline: Europe to Remove 500-Euro Bill, the ‘Bin Laden’ Bank Note Criminals Love
articles.snippet: Though the effort has been portrayed as a blow to corruption and organized crime, some critics say it is as an infringement on personal freedom and a stealthy tool of monetary policy.
articles.abstract: Though the effort has been portrayed as a blow to corruption and organized crime, some critics say it is as an infringement on personal freedom and a stealthy tool of monetary policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — A suitcase stuffed full of cash may soon be worth a lot less.

articles.headline: U.S. Warns North Carolina That Transgender Bill Violates Civil Rights Laws
articles.snippet: The Justice Department said the measure violates federal law under Title VII, which prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department said the measure violates federal law under Title VII, which prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department warned the State of North Carolina on Wednesday that its new law limiting bathroom access violated the civil rights of transgender people, a finding that could mean millions of dollars in lost federal funds.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: Infighting Threatens to Fell a Venture Capital Firm
articles.snippet: Xfund, which manages more than $100 million and has funded start-ups, is in salvage mode.
articles.abstract: Xfund, which manages more than $100 million and has funded start-ups, is in salvage mode.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Xfund, a venture capital firm formed in 2011 as technology start-ups boomed, began coming undone last year when the relationship between its two partners soured.

articles.headline: Another Combat Death in Iraq May Presage Future U.S. Role
articles.snippet: Tuesday’s battle in Teleskof could presage a future in Iraq where American troops move even closer to routine, daily battle in the fight against ISIS.
articles.abstract: Tuesday’s battle in Teleskof could presage a future in Iraq where American troops move even closer to routine, daily battle in the fight against ISIS.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Islamic State fighters arrived on the outskirts of the northern Iraqi town of Teleskof before dawn. Launching a sophisticated attack from multiple directions, they used armored bulldozers to plow over a protective trench so their convoy of trucks — some laden with explosives — could drive deep into the town. Residents and some local soldiers quickly fled.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Rule on Arbitration Would Restore Right to Sue Banks
articles.snippet: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is proposing a rule that would limit clauses forcing customers to agree to arbitration instead of pursuing class-action suits.
articles.abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is proposing a rule that would limit clauses forcing customers to agree to arbitration instead of pursuing class-action suits.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s consumer watchdog is unveiling a proposed rule on Thursday that would restore customers’ rights to bring class-action lawsuits against financial firms, giving Americans major new protections and delivering a serious blow to Wall Street that could cost the industry billions of dollars.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: The Republican Horse Race Is Over, and Journalism Lost
articles.snippet: Political journalists’ mistakes piled up as they played down the rise of Donald Trump as a serious candidate and emphasized his entertainment value.
articles.abstract: Political journalists’ mistakes piled up as they played down the rise of Donald Trump as a serious candidate and emphasized his entertainment value.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wrong, wrong, wrong — to the very end, we got it wrong.

articles.headline: One Week in April, Four Toddlers Shot and Killed Themselves
articles.snippet: Shootings by preschoolers are happening at an average pace of about two per week. A child who accidentally pulls the trigger is most likely to be 3 years old.
articles.abstract: Shootings by preschoolers are happening at an average pace of about two per week. A child who accidentally pulls the trigger is most likely to be 3 years old.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Sha’Quille Kornegay, 2 years old, was buried in a pink coffin, her favorite doll by her side and a tiara strategically placed to hide the self-inflicted gunshot wound to her forehead.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Julie Bosman, Alan Blinder and Julie Turkewitz
